Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the frequency of snowstorms, stating that they happen every 10 or 15 years when they may occur more frequently.
Understate: The claim may be understating the severity and impact of the recent snowstorm by comparing it to previous snowstorms that did not have the same lingering impact.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough supporting evidence or data to substantiate the frequency of the snowstorms.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the recent snowstorm was a "perfect storm" that only occurs every decade or so, without considering other factors that may have contributed to its severity.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the differences in impact between previous snowstorms and the recent one, such as the presence of Arctic air blast after the snowfall.
